EDIT: this post is really dumb I don't understand how it got upvotes, Sion has no interaction with allies whatsoever and is thus not a Warden, even if his CC is sometimes used to peel. Same goes for any tank.

This. For a champion to be a Warden, they need to have abilities expressly designed to protect, or at the very least assist allies. Sion has no ally-oriented abilities, which makes him a Vanguard.

At the same time, though, I don't think piling all non-Wardens into the Vanguard class really works, because different Vanguards do very different things. Sion, for example, mostly exists to provide area denial and disrupt multiple enemies at a time, as do tanks like Amumu and Sejuani. By contrast, champions like Leona, Nautilus or Rammus are mostly good at locking down one single target really, really hard. These champions play very differently from each other and, most of the time, are also valued for different strengths: the former tank subclass is really good at initiating, for example, because they usually have large AoE hard CC on their ult, whereas the latter is better at roaming and ganking, i.e. dealing with isolated targets. Riot might need to separate the Vanguard subclass into two more, especially since they're going to be updating a lot of tanks soon.
I'm glad Riot came up with all these retarded titles so we can spend even more time pointlessly splitting hairs

Sion's Q is much much more powerful defensively (used to zone or peel) than offensively, except when he hits his ulti. Which, I was making a point of talking about.

Sion's e also shreds armor, which is fantastic for if you're peeling for an adc. 

But his q is much less likely to get interrupted if used defensively, and the enemy diver/assassin can't really be like "oh ok I'll just walk out of this" while the backline of a team very easily can.

This, of course, all changes if you land a long range ulti.
